mcq.q: The basic process of exchanging information from one location (source) to a destination is called _______.
Which of the following is NOT a basic block of a communication system?
The component that prepares data into an appropriate format for transmission over the channel is the _______.
The process of converting a continuous-time signal to a discrete-time signal is known as _______.
The process of converting continuous-amplitude samples into a finite set of discrete amplitude levels is called _______.
The primary goal of a _______ is to remove redundancy and represent the signal efficiently using as few bits as possible.
The primary goal of a _______ is to add extra bits to help detect and correct errors.
The process of impressing information onto the amplitude, phase, or frequency of a carrier wave is called _______.
Which of the following is a type of guided communication channel?
The guided medium that consists of two insulated copper wires twisted around each other to reduce EMI is called _______.
The transmission medium that is immune to electromagnetic interference (EMI) is _______.
Hollow metallic structures that guide high-frequency signals like microwaves are known as _______.
An undesired effect from the communication environment, usually not under our control, is called _______.
Intentional interference aimed at destroying the quality of the transmitted signal is known as _______.
The information generated by an application that needs to be transmitted is called _______.
The representation of data in a communication system, such as electricity in a wire, is called a _______.
A traditional telephone system is an example of which combination?
Voice over IP (VoIP) is a common example of which combination?
Modern computer networks like Ethernet and Wi-Fi typically use which combination?

tf.q: The OSI model consists of 7 layers.
A receiver prepares the data in an appropriate format to be transmitted over the channel.
tf.correction: The transmitter does this.

tf.q: In the Analog-to-Digital conversion process, quantization happens before sampling.
tf.correction: Sampling is the first step.

tf.q: Source encoding's main focus is to add redundancy for error correction.
tf.correction: Its focus is to remove redundancy (compression).

tf.q: MP3 compression is an example of source encoding.
The channel encoder's goal is to improve reliability by adding extra bits for error control.
Twisting the wires in a twisted-pair cable increases electromagnetic interference (EMI).
tf.correction: It reduces EMI.

tf.q: Coaxial cables offer better protection against external noise compared to unshielded twisted pair cables.
Optical fibers transmit data using electrical signals.
tf.correction: They use light signals.

tf.q: A satellite is an example of a guided communication channel.
tf.correction: It is an unguided channel.

tf.q: Jamming is an unintentional form of interference.
tf.correction: It is intentional.

tf.q: A digital pulse signal maintains its perfect shape as it travels over long distances.
tf.correction: The signal degrades and needs regeneration.

tf.q: In a communication system, the terms 'data' and 'signal' are interchangeable and mean the exact same thing.
tf.correction: Data is the information, and the signal is its physical representation.

tf.q: A modem used in early internet connections is an example of Digital Data, Digital Signal.
tf.correction: It's an example of Digital Data, Analog Signal.

mcq.q: A signal in which the intensity varies in a smooth fashion over time is called a _______ signal.
A signal that maintains a constant level and then changes to another constant level is called a _______ signal.
Which of these is used in digital systems to represent binary data (0s and 1s)?
The peak value (height) of a sine wave, representing its strength, is called its _______.
The number of complete cycles a sine wave makes per second is called its _______.
The time it takes for a sine wave to complete one full cycle is called its _______.
The horizontal shift, or starting point, of a sine wave on the time axis is called its _______.
What is the correct mathematical relationship between Period (T) and Frequency (f)?
The mathematical tool used to decompose a complex signal into its simple sine wave components is called _______.
The range of frequencies contained within a signal is called its _______.
A component of zero frequency (f=0) in a signal's spectrum is known as a _______ component.
The difference between the upper and lower frequencies in a continuous band is called _______.
Which of the following applications typically requires the largest bandwidth?
A perfect square wave (ideal digital signal) theoretically has _______ bandwidth.
Which equation correctly describes a sine wave?

tf.q: A square wave is an example of a continuous signal.
tf.correction: It is an example of a discrete signal.

tf.q: In the equation s(t) = A sin(2πft + φ), 'A' represents the frequency.
tf.correction: It represents the Amplitude (peak strength).

tf.q: If a signal has a frequency of 10 Hz, its period (T) is 0.1 seconds.
A sine wave with a phase (φ) of 0 starts at its maximum peak value.
tf.correction: It starts at the 0 value, going positive.

tf.q: Any complex signal, including a square wave, can be represented as a sum of simple sine waves.
The 'spectrum' of a signal shows how its amplitude changes over time.
tf.correction: It shows the range of frequencies the signal contains.

tf.q: A DC component in a signal has a frequency of 0 Hz.
Higher bandwidth in a communication channel allows for slower data rates.
tf.correction: It allows for faster data rates.

tf.q: AM radio uses a larger bandwidth than FM radio.
tf.correction: FM radio uses a much larger bandwidth (e.g., 200 kHz vs 10 kHz).

tf.q: A digital signal (square wave) requires a large bandwidth to be transmitted accurately.
tf.correction: A larger bandwidth is needed to represent the sharp edges.

mcq.q: The principle that allows light to propagate through an optical fiber is called _______.
For Total Internal Reflection to occur, the refractive index of the Core (n1) must be _______ the refractive index of the Cladding (n2).
Which advantage of optical fiber means it is not affected by electrical noise from nearby cables?
Which fiber type has a very small core (8-10 microns) and is used for long-distance communication?
Which fiber type has a larger core (50-62.5 microns) and is typically used for LANs and Data Centers?
The reduction or loss of signal power as it travels along the fiber is called _______.
Attenuation in optical fiber is typically measured in which unit?
The widening or 'smearing' of a light pulse as it travels, which limits the data rate, is called _______.
When pulse widening causes neighboring pulses (bits) to overlap, this is known as _______.
Which type of dispersion occurs ONLY in Multimode Fiber (MMF) because light takes multiple paths?
Which type of dispersion occurs because different wavelengths (colors) of light travel at different speeds?
Which type of dispersion occurs in SMF due to fiber imperfections, causing different polarization states to travel at different speeds?
A device that takes an input signal from one fiber and splits it into N output fibers is called a _______.
In an 8x8 Passive Star Coupler (PSC), if the input power is 100mW, what is the ideal power received at each output port?
PSCs are commonly used in which type of network topology where one signal is distributed to many receivers?

tf.q: In an optical fiber, the cladding has a higher refractive index than the core.
tf.correction: The core has a higher refractive index (n1 > n2).

tf.q: Optical fibers are immune to EMI because they transmit light instead of electrical signals.
Single-mode fiber (SMF) has a larger core and supports more light paths than Multimode fiber (MMF).
tf.correction: MMF has the larger core and supports multiple paths.

tf.q: Attenuation is the primary factor that limits the data rate, while dispersion limits the maximum distance.
tf.correction: Dispersion limits the data rate (causes ISI), while attenuation limits the distance.

tf.q: Modal dispersion occurs in both single-mode and multimode fibers.
tf.correction: Modal dispersion occurs only in multimode fibers (MMF).

tf.q: Chromatic dispersion occurs because different wavelengths (colors) travel at different speeds.
Polarization Mode Dispersion (PMD) is a significant problem in multimode fibers.
tf.correction: It is a problem primarily in single-mode fibers (SMF).

tf.q: Nonlinear effects like FWM occur when the light intensity in the fiber is very low.
tf.correction: They occur when the light intensity is very high.

tf.q: A 1xN device is a combiner, and an Nx1 device is a splitter.
tf.correction: A 1xN is a splitter, and an Nx1 is a combiner.

tf.q: Passive Star Couplers (PSC) are called 'passive' because they do not require an external power source.
In a 1x2 splitter with a 50/50 coupling ratio, each output port receives 50% of the input power.
Optical fiber cables are heavier and larger than copper cables.
tf.correction: They are significantly lightweight and thinner.

tf.q: A '3 dB coupler' is a term for a 1x2 splitter that divides the power equally (50/50).
tf.correction: A 3dB loss corresponds to a 50% reduction in power.

mcq.q: The acronym LASER stands for Light Amplification by _______ Emission of Radiation.
The process that allows a laser to produce intense, coherent beams of light is called _______.
The stable, lowest possible energy level for an electron in an atom is called the _______.
When an atom absorbs energy, it moves to a higher, unstable energy level known as the _______.
A state where an excited electron can stay for a longer period before returning to the ground state is called a _______.
The critical condition for lasing, where there are more electrons in the excited state than in the ground state, is called _______.
Which component of a laser provides the energy to achieve population inversion?
Which component of a laser allows a small portion of the amplified light to exit as the laser beam?
In stimulated emission, the new photon released is _______ the original photon.
In a laser cavity, what component controls the frequency of the emitted light?
The simple and common laser type used in optical communication, implemented with a p-n junction, is the _______.
The 'spectral width' of the light generated by a laser is known as its _______.
Variations in the laser's frequency, such as 'mode hopping' or 'mode shifts', are called _______.
It is desirable to use lasers with a single longitudinal mode to avoid _______.
Lasers that can change their output wavelength are needed for _______ networks.
Which type of tunable laser offers a very wide tuning range but suffers from a slow tuning time?
An alternative to a tunable laser is a _______, which integrates multiple fixed-tuned lasers on one component.

tf.q: LASER stands for Light Amplification by Spontaneous Emission of Radiation.
tf.correction: It stands for Light Amplification by STIMULATED Emission of Radiation.

tf.q: In the 'ground state', an atom's electrons are in the highest possible energy levels.
tf.correction: They are in the lowest possible energy levels.

tf.q: Population inversion means there are more electrons in the ground state than in the excited state.
tf.correction: It means there are MORE electrons in the EXCITED state.

tf.q: The Lasing Medium in a laser is made of a quasi-stable substance.
In a laser, two partially-transmitting mirrors are used at both ends.
tf.correction: One is fully reflective, and the other is partially-transmitting.

tf.q: Stimulated emission occurs when a photon passes near an electron in the ground state.
tf.correction: It occurs when a photon passes near an EXCITED electron.

tf.q: Semiconductor diode lasers are complex and rarely used in optical communication.
tf.correction: They are very simple and commonly used.

tf.q: 'Laser linewidth' refers to the physical width of the laser device.
tf.correction: It refers to the spectral (frequency) width of the light it emits.

tf.q: 'Mode hopping' is a type of frequency instability in lasers.
Lasers that produce multiple longitudinal modes are ideal for communication.
tf.correction: They are undesirable as they cause significant dispersion.

tf.q: Tunable lasers are required for WDM (Wavelength Division Multiplexing) networks.
Mechanically-tuned lasers are very fast but have a narrow tuning range.
tf.correction: They are very SLOW but have a WIDE tuning range.

tf.q: The main drawback of Injection-Current-Tuned lasers is 'mode hopping'.
A laser array consists of a single laser that can be tuned to different wavelengths.
tf.correction: It consists of multiple FIXED-tuned lasers integrated into a single component.

tf.q: An advantage of a laser array is that each wavelength can be modulated independently and simultaneously.

mcq.q: The process of altering properties of light (like amplitude or phase) to carry information is called _______.
In optical systems, Amplitude Shift Keying (ASK) is most commonly known as _______.
In On-Off Keying (OOK) modulation, a 'Binary 1' is represented by _______ and a 'Binary 0' by _______.
Which modulation technique changes the phase (e.g., 0° or 180°) of the light wave and is more reliable for long distances?
How many bits per symbol does Quadrature Phase Shift Keying (QPSK) encode?
Which advanced modulation technique modulates BOTH the amplitude and the phase of the light wave for higher efficiency?
How many bits per symbol does 16-QAM transmit?
The primary role of an optical receiver is to convert the received _______ signal back into an _______ signal.
Which type of receiver converts the optical signal directly to current using a photodetector, and only measures intensity?
Direct Detection receivers are simple, cost-effective, and suitable for _______ modulation.
Which receiver type uses a 'Local Oscillator' (a reference laser) to detect both amplitude and phase?
Advanced modulation formats like QPSK and QAM require a _______ receiver.
A key advantage of Coherent Detection is its ability to compensate for impairments like _______ using DSP.
A device used to selectively transmit or block certain wavelengths (colors) of light is an _______.
Which type of filter reflects a specific wavelength and transmits all others?
A Mach-Zehnder Interferometer (MZI) filter separates wavelengths based on the principle of _______.
In an MZI, wavelengths are filtered out (cancelled) if they recombine with a phase difference of _______.
What does the 'D' in DWDM stand for?
What DWDM component combines multiple wavelengths (colors) from different sources into a single fiber?
What DWDM component separates the mixed wavelengths from one fiber back into individual channels?
What DWDM component converts a standard optical signal (e.g., 1310nm) into a precise DWDM wavelength (e.g., 1550nm)?
What device is used at an intermediate node to 'drop' one wavelength and 'add' another?
What component is placed along the fiber link to compensate for 'Attenuation' (signal loss)?
What component is placed along the fiber link to compensate for 'Dispersion' (pulse widening)?
What device is used to reduce the power of an optical signal, often to balance power between channels?

tf.q: FSK (Frequency Shift Keying) is the most common and efficient modulation in optical systems.
tf.correction: It is rarely used and less common due to lower spectral efficiency.

tf.q: QAM is highly efficient because it modulates both the amplitude and phase of the light wave.
Direct Detection receivers are suitable for low-cost, short-range systems like FTTH.
Direct Detection receivers can easily decode PSK and QAM signals.
tf.correction: They only measure intensity, not phase, so they cannot decode PSK or QAM.

tf.q: Coherent Detection receivers use a 'Local Oscillator' (a reference laser).
Coherent Detection is simpler and cheaper than Direct Detection.
tf.correction: It is more complex and expensive.

tf.q: A Fiber Bragg Grating (FBG) works by allowing a specific wavelength to pass and reflecting all others.
tf.correction: It REFLECTS a specific wavelength and allows all others to pass.

tf.q: A Mach-Zehnder Interferometer (MZI) can be tuned by varying the temperature.
Tuning an MZI filter by temperature is a very fast process (ns range).
tf.correction: It is a slow process (ms range).

tf.q: A MUX (Multiplexer) separates a single combined signal into multiple wavelengths.
tf.correction: A MUX combines signals. A DEMUX separates them.

tf.q: An OADM (Optical Add/Drop Multiplexer) can only be placed at the beginning or end of a network.
tf.correction: It is used at intermediate nodes to add/drop channels.

tf.q: An EDFA amplifies the optical signal to compensate for Attenuation.
A DCM (Dispersion Compensator) is used to compensate for Attenuation.
tf.correction: It is used to compensate for Dispersion (pulse widening).

tf.q: A VOA (Variable Optical Attenuator) is a type of amplifier.
tf.correction: It is the opposite; it reduces (attenuates) the signal power.
